description: In this course, users will learn foundations for capturing video and how to edit in Premiere Pro, the leading video editing software from the Adobe Creative Cloud suite. Topics include importing media, using the timeline, adding transitions and effects, mixing audio, color correction, and exporting options.
descriptionMD: In this course, users will learn foundations for capturing video and how to edit in Premiere Pro, the leading video editing software from the Adobe Creative Cloud suite. Topics include importing media, using the timeline, adding transitions and effects, mixing audio, color correction, and exporting options.
name: Premiere Pro CC 2017
subtitle: Video Editing Application

episodes.description: James and Vonne introduce commonly used terminology for working in video editing and Premiere Pro.
episodes.title: Read Me
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.012 --> 00:00:05.466
[SOUND]

2
00:00:05.466 --> 00:00:11.517
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:11.517 --> 00:00:14.153
Hello everyone and
welcome to Creative Pro TV.

4
00:00:14.153 --> 00:00:17.095
I'm your host, Vonne Smith, and

5
00:00:17.095 --> 00:00:22.984
we are starting a brand new series
in Adobe Premiere Pro CC 2017.

6
00:00:22.984 --> 00:00:27.880
And we're really excited to have the one
and only, the expert, Mr. James Biddle.

7
00:00:27.880 --> 00:00:30.763
[LAUGH]
>> Great, thanks for making it easy on me.

8
00:00:30.763 --> 00:00:33.423
>> I know, I love when Daniel does that.

9
00:00:33.423 --> 00:00:38.420
The total expert on this, like well-
>> No pressure, no pressure, no pressure.

10
00:00:38.420 --> 00:00:39.360
>> I know, right?

11
00:00:39.360 --> 00:00:40.498
[LAUGH]
>> Goodness.

12
00:00:40.498 --> 00:00:41.951
Well Vonne, it's great to be here.

13
00:00:41.951 --> 00:00:44.065
>> I know, well I'm really excited for
this series-

14
00:00:44.065 --> 00:00:45.085
>> Me too.

15
00:00:45.085 --> 00:00:47.160
>> To learn all about our Premiere and
some video editing.

16
00:00:47.160 --> 00:00:49.154
And we're starting from
the very beginning.

17
00:00:49.154 --> 00:00:50.280
>> Yep.
>> We're gonna take it from

18
00:00:50.280 --> 00:00:53.725
a base level and move up, because we
talked about it, and this is our overview.

19
00:00:53.725 --> 00:00:54.660
>> Yeah.

20
00:00:54.660 --> 00:00:56.363
>> We're actually filming this last, and

21
00:00:56.363 --> 00:00:59.381
we've actually gone through all
the episodes and I've learned a lot.

22
00:00:59.381 --> 00:01:01.944
>> Good.
>> But I wanted to kind of go ahead and

23
00:01:01.944 --> 00:01:06.213
just get a quick frame of reference for
just some terminology.

24
00:01:06.213 --> 00:01:08.383
And I love how we-
>> Sure.

25
00:01:08.383 --> 00:01:10.066
>> Read me cuz-
>> Yeah, the read me file,

26
00:01:10.066 --> 00:01:11.369
no one ever reads the read me file.

27
00:01:11.369 --> 00:01:13.507
>> Right [LAUGH]
>> Read the read me file.

28
00:01:13.507 --> 00:01:15.307
>> Yes, read the instructions.

29
00:01:15.307 --> 00:01:16.155
>> Please read the instructions.

30
00:01:16.155 --> 00:01:20.972
>> And so one thing that I do
when I'm learning a product is

31
00:01:20.972 --> 00:01:24.233
I wanna know the right terminology.

32
00:01:24.233 --> 00:01:29.270
>> Yeah.
>> So that way I can use it wrongly.

33
00:01:29.270 --> 00:01:34.263
>> Exactly, we do have some standardized
language within editing and within Adobe,

34
00:01:34.263 --> 00:01:37.772
but you're always going to
say something that's close.

35
00:01:37.772 --> 00:01:42.496
For example, the timeline is a tool and
sequences go in it, but

36
00:01:42.496 --> 00:01:47.773
everybody just says show me the sequence,
show me the sequence tool.

37
00:01:47.773 --> 00:01:48.286
>> Yeah.

38
00:01:48.286 --> 00:01:50.355
>> I mean it just happens that way.

39
00:01:50.355 --> 00:01:54.381
>> Yeah,and I think it's from just being
in the industry and you just start using

40
00:01:54.381 --> 00:01:58.529
this terminology and you just use it like
it's regular language for you, but for

41
00:01:58.529 --> 00:02:02.572
me like an outsider coming in, it's like
wait, was that a sequence or a clip?

42
00:02:02.572 --> 00:02:05.590
Wait, is it a clip and
a media the same thing?

43
00:02:05.590 --> 00:02:07.870
>> It's a media and file and
then everything's going crazy so, yeah.

44
00:02:07.870 --> 00:02:09.828
There are some things you
wanna embed in there.

45
00:02:09.828 --> 00:02:11.414
Don't get it wrong but

46
00:02:11.414 --> 00:02:15.920
in other cases you can fudge out
a couple of times, it's okay.

47
00:02:15.920 --> 00:02:19.870
>> Yeah, cuz I know when we go
through all these episodes you

48
00:02:19.870 --> 00:02:22.420
really explain all of this and
I'm, I get it.

49
00:02:22.420 --> 00:02:25.987
But it took me a couple episodes to
kinda clear it in my mind of exactly

50
00:02:25.987 --> 00:02:27.689
the sequence and the segments.

51
00:02:27.689 --> 00:02:29.282
>> Sure.
>> So I've actually made a few notes.

52
00:02:29.282 --> 00:02:30.245
>> Okay.
>> If you don't mind,

53
00:02:30.245 --> 00:02:32.501
I'm just gonna go ahead and
ask you a few things and

54
00:02:32.501 --> 00:02:34.614
do a quick overview of
explaining something.

55
00:02:34.614 --> 00:02:37.907
>> Hit me with the notes, just don't
hit me like you hit me after the show.

56
00:02:37.907 --> 00:02:38.407
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay.

57
00:02:38.407 --> 00:02:39.440
>> [LAUGH] All right, I'll-

58
00:02:39.440 --> 00:02:40.039
>> Help me.

59
00:02:40.039 --> 00:02:41.367
>> I'll be gentle. [LAUGH] >> All right.

60
00:02:41.367 --> 00:02:42.178
Good.

61
00:02:42.178 --> 00:02:43.940
>> So we have media versus clip,

62
00:02:43.940 --> 00:02:47.650
is it the same thing?
>> Right, okay, no.

63
00:02:47.650 --> 00:02:49.887
So media is essence, it's what you shot on

64
00:02:49.887 --> 00:02:54.174
your camera or it's the actual file that
you've, you can see it as a quick timer,

65
00:02:54.174 --> 00:02:58.589
a JPEG, or something like that.
Once it is brought into Premiere,

66
00:02:58.589 --> 00:03:02.171
it becomes what we call a clip or
a masterclip.

67
00:03:02.171 --> 00:03:04.138
That is metadata that

68
00:03:04.138 --> 00:03:08.100
represents the media.
And that's why clips, you can change.

69
00:03:08.100 --> 00:03:09.780
You can make them longer or shorter.

70
00:03:09.780 --> 00:03:10.501
You can rename them.

71
00:03:10.501 --> 00:03:12.452
You can add effects to them and

72
00:03:12.452 --> 00:03:16.232
it doesn't affect the actual media.
It stays the same.

73
00:03:16.232 --> 00:03:17.840
>> It's kinda like a nickname,

74
00:03:17.840 --> 00:03:21.389
like we're nicknaming this
particular thing that's [CROSSTALK]

75
00:03:21.389 --> 00:03:23.223
>> Nicknaming or I often say,

76
00:03:23.223 --> 00:03:26.985
the media is the parts and
the clip is the instructions.

77
00:03:26.985 --> 00:03:28.029
And I can change it,

78
00:03:28.029 --> 00:03:32.148
I could rewrite the instructions, put it
in a nice glossy binder, do all that,

79
00:03:32.148 --> 00:03:34.251
doesn't change the parts.
>> Okay.

80
00:03:34.251 --> 00:03:34.763
>> Yeah.

81
00:03:34.763 --> 00:03:36.087
>> Great, all right, wonderful.

82
00:03:36.087 --> 00:03:38.823
Now when we talk about audio, I feel it's

83
00:03:38.823 --> 00:03:43.904
the whole of how we capture it and then
there's an audio clip cuz we understand

84
00:03:43.904 --> 00:03:47.170
that clips when it's coming to Premiere.
>> Right.

85
00:03:47.170 --> 00:03:48.775
>> But then when it goes somewhere

86
00:03:48.775 --> 00:03:50.975
else it becomes a track?
>> Right,

87
00:03:50.975 --> 00:03:52.760
so-
>> Or am I jumping the gun a little?

88
00:03:52.760 --> 00:03:54.290
>> No, no, no, you're fine, you're fine.

89
00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:56.560
The thing is when you get into audio,

90
00:03:56.560 --> 00:03:59.910
people who do an audio has a very,
very specialized language,

91
00:03:59.910 --> 00:04:02.260
mostly because they don't
want to talk to anybody else.

92
00:04:02.260 --> 00:04:05.030
And if you don't speak their language
they'll just go, [SOUND] and walk away.

93
00:04:05.030 --> 00:04:09.200
When we bring in media, okay?

94
00:04:09.200 --> 00:04:15.100
We think of that as input and
we say that something has channels.

95
00:04:15.100 --> 00:04:18.470
So if you record on a camera,
you have two channels maybe, or

96
00:04:18.470 --> 00:04:20.550
some cameras record like eight channels.

97
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:23.260
Or maybe you recorded on a device
that gave you four channels.

98
00:04:23.260 --> 00:04:25.362
That's considered an input.

99
00:04:25.362 --> 00:04:30.285
So when you put it into a sequence,
that's when you see

100
00:04:30.285 --> 00:04:35.325
movies where guys do a mixer and
doing stuff like [SOUND].

101
00:04:35.325 --> 00:04:35.871
>> Mm-hm.

102
00:04:35.871 --> 00:04:38.590
>> And they say we need more tracks, man.

103
00:04:38.590 --> 00:04:41.934
That's the thing is that
on the output side,

104
00:04:41.934 --> 00:04:45.430
which is the sequence side,
you have tracks.

105
00:04:45.430 --> 00:04:49.686
And that's why something with
two channels, or eight channels,

106
00:04:49.686 --> 00:04:51.137
can go in to one track.

107
00:04:51.137 --> 00:04:52.670
>> And that's where I use the wrong C.

108
00:04:53.690 --> 00:04:56.237
I said clips but when you said channels,
I was yes, that's right.

109
00:04:56.237 --> 00:04:56.840
>> Channels.

110
00:04:56.840 --> 00:04:58.090
>> Cuz you were saying channels.

111
00:04:58.090 --> 00:05:01.700
And I think that's another one where
there's the input and the output are like,

112
00:05:01.700 --> 00:05:04.930
how you captured it with your device-
>> Right.

113
00:05:04.930 --> 00:05:09.410
>> When it comes into Premiere and
then how it goes out of Premiere and

114
00:05:09.410 --> 00:05:10.800
all that kind of stuff-
>> Exactly.

115
00:05:10.800 --> 00:05:13.700
I think we talked a couple of times,
I like to think

116
00:05:13.700 --> 00:05:18.020
of the left side as the input side and
the right side is the output side.

117
00:05:18.020 --> 00:05:21.895
That's why you have different language,
like we have clips and channels and

118
00:05:21.895 --> 00:05:26.261
gain for audio, when we're adjusting how
loud or soft it is, we're adjusting gain.

119
00:05:26.261 --> 00:05:28.932
Cuz we always said on audio input,
you have gain.

120
00:05:28.932 --> 00:05:31.907
On output, you have volume.

121
00:05:31.907 --> 00:05:33.450
>> Yes.

122
00:05:33.450 --> 00:05:37.062
>> So left side, we have clips,
we have channels, we have gain.

123
00:05:37.062 --> 00:05:41.090
On the right side,
which is the output side,

124
00:05:41.090 --> 00:05:45.980
we have segments, we have volume,
and we have tracks.

125
00:05:45.980 --> 00:05:47.180
>> Yeah, and we explain all of this.

126
00:05:47.180 --> 00:05:50.040
You explain it very well
in all these episodes.

127
00:05:50.040 --> 00:05:54.340
So again, we're just doing
listen to the terminology.

128
00:05:54.340 --> 00:05:55.530
When we're saying left and right,

129
00:05:55.530 --> 00:06:00.310
we're talking about the physical
sides of the program.

130
00:06:00.310 --> 00:06:04.386
>> We can take a quick look right
now at the interface, okay?

131
00:06:04.386 --> 00:06:07.190
Because what we do is we have panels.

132
00:06:07.190 --> 00:06:09.530
So we have panels, we have panel groups.

133
00:06:09.530 --> 00:06:12.795
And then everything that's
sort of on the left side.

134
00:06:12.795 --> 00:06:16.325
Okay, everything that's on
this left side right here.

135
00:06:16.325 --> 00:06:19.953
The source and the project,
that's what I'm considering the left side,

136
00:06:19.953 --> 00:06:22.442
the input side because this
where we get our clips.

137
00:06:22.442 --> 00:06:27.891
The source area is where we take
a clip and we modify it, okay?

138
00:06:27.891 --> 00:06:34.960
I'm only gonna take this much right here,
and you'll learn this as I'm doing it.

139
00:06:34.960 --> 00:06:39.332
I have marked a segment of
this that I'm going to use,

140
00:06:39.332 --> 00:06:43.033
and then I bring it down
here to the sequence.

141
00:06:43.033 --> 00:06:49.081
And now I've used a segment of this clip
which now I can adjust it to volume or

142
00:06:49.081 --> 00:06:52.640
on this side I could've adjusted its gain.

143
00:06:52.640 --> 00:06:55.880
>> Yeah and see right there, the whole,
okay here is the clip we went in and

144
00:06:55.880 --> 00:06:56.477
the source.

145
00:06:56.477 --> 00:07:00.704
That's not a part of just understanding
the names of the windows or

146
00:07:00.704 --> 00:07:03.798
panels, cuz we use those
words interchangeably

147
00:07:03.798 --> 00:07:07.362
within what we call the workspace
of any Adobe product.

148
00:07:07.362 --> 00:07:08.894
>> Yeah.

149
00:07:08.894 --> 00:07:11.054
Cuz all of these window panel
thingies that we go in.

150
00:07:11.054 --> 00:07:12.858
>> Right.
>> So it's like project,

151
00:07:12.858 --> 00:07:16.205
okay that's that name, source,
and then it comes down.

152
00:07:16.205 --> 00:07:19.030
Again that terminology of go up, go up,

153
00:07:19.030 --> 00:07:19.620
go up and-
>> Right.

154
00:07:19.620 --> 00:07:20.540
>> Yes, that's right.

155
00:07:20.540 --> 00:07:22.055
>> And that's the thing I couldn't say.

156
00:07:22.055 --> 00:07:25.320
Cuz technically this is
the project panel group.

157
00:07:25.320 --> 00:07:26.750
And there are things within it.

158
00:07:26.750 --> 00:07:27.712
This is the source panel group.

159
00:07:27.712 --> 00:07:30.810
The source panel which has a panel group.

160
00:07:30.810 --> 00:07:34.130
And I could make that very clear
the entire time, but then I would go very,

161
00:07:34.130 --> 00:07:37.940
very slow and be worried more about
saying it correctly than having fun and

162
00:07:37.940 --> 00:07:38.630
showing you what to do.

163
00:07:38.630 --> 00:07:40.690
>> Yeah.
>> One last thing I want to show about

164
00:07:40.690 --> 00:07:43.260
the left-right, and
to explain channel tracks.

165
00:07:44.600 --> 00:07:46.190
This left side in the sequence,

166
00:07:46.190 --> 00:07:50.640
and we're gonna talk about this
several times, represents the source.

167
00:07:50.640 --> 00:07:55.080
And it has a video channel and
an audio channel.

168
00:07:55.080 --> 00:08:02.808
This represents the sequence which has
three video tracks and four audio tracks.

169
00:08:02.808 --> 00:08:09.380
>> That's where you're actually
doing all of the editing.

170
00:08:09.380 --> 00:08:10.408
>> Right, that's where we actually.

171
00:08:10.408 --> 00:08:14.418
>> Even within Premiere, we can do all
these, I keep calling them layers, and

172
00:08:14.418 --> 00:08:18.490
I keep referring to it throughout the
series, because I see it as layers, but

173
00:08:18.490 --> 00:08:20.079
these are tracks [CROSSTALK].

174
00:08:20.079 --> 00:08:24.142
>> If you're a Photoshop user or even
sometimes an After Effects user coming

175
00:08:24.142 --> 00:08:28.418
into Premiere, you're gonna use
the language that you're used to, okay?

176
00:08:28.418 --> 00:08:30.973
And eventually you'll realize
when you bounce back and

177
00:08:30.973 --> 00:08:34.890
forth between applications there's new
terms of different terms because different

178
00:08:34.890 --> 00:08:37.515
types of professionals use
different apps all the time.

179
00:08:37.515 --> 00:08:40.441
It happens, don't feel bad, yeah.

180
00:08:40.441 --> 00:08:42.456
Some people are just gonna tell you, well,

181
00:08:42.456 --> 00:08:44.530
they actually really
should be same tracks.

182
00:08:44.530 --> 00:08:46.070
I mean, it's fine.

183
00:08:46.070 --> 00:08:46.660
>> Yeah.

184
00:08:46.660 --> 00:08:48.570
>> Just take the ribbing and move on.

185
00:08:48.570 --> 00:08:49.223
>> Yeah, exactly.
And

186
00:08:49.223 --> 00:08:53.029
it's because I've been with you this
whole week and you're going through this.

187
00:08:53.029 --> 00:08:53.588
>> Right.

188
00:08:53.588 --> 00:08:55.217
Yep, there's that terminology.

189
00:08:55.217 --> 00:08:58.485
It's already clicking,
the more you hear it and

190
00:08:58.485 --> 00:09:03.583
the more you see it in action as we go
through everything, it will get it, but

191
00:09:03.583 --> 00:09:09.028
I just wanted to kinda go through some of
those super basics of what is a sequence-

192
00:09:09.028 --> 00:09:09.842
>> Right.

193
00:09:09.842 --> 00:09:12.270
>> Because the sequence is over on
the timeline, and that's where-

194
00:09:12.270 --> 00:09:13.185
>> Yep.

195
00:09:13.185 --> 00:09:15.311
>> We'll be doing the editing,

196
00:09:15.311 --> 00:09:19.085
but the segments are what
you want out of your clips.

197
00:09:19.085 --> 00:09:20.611
[CROSSTALK] that was your media.

198
00:09:20.611 --> 00:09:22.668
>> And then it becomes a game.

199
00:09:22.668 --> 00:09:23.725
>> Yeah.

200
00:09:23.725 --> 00:09:24.352
>> [LAUGH] Right.
>> Yeah.

201
00:09:24.352 --> 00:09:28.762
And so we'll use different words-
>> Yeah.

202
00:09:28.762 --> 00:09:32.300
>> Throughout here, but we're just kinda-
>> And you'll catch us doing that and

203
00:09:32.300 --> 00:09:32.854
fun with it.

204
00:09:32.854 --> 00:09:37.201
Have fun with the fact that you caught
us saying maybe something slightly,

205
00:09:37.201 --> 00:09:38.850
have fun with it please.

206
00:09:38.850 --> 00:09:43.350
>> Yeah, because I do the same
thing that the That's not right.

207
00:09:43.350 --> 00:09:44.175
>> No, no, no.

208
00:09:44.175 --> 00:09:45.977
>> No, bad kitty.
>> Bad kitty.

209
00:09:45.977 --> 00:09:46.564
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.
So

210
00:09:46.564 --> 00:09:48.599
I just want to kind of get a frame-up and

211
00:09:48.599 --> 00:09:51.018
we do mention a lot about
hot keys in this show.

212
00:09:51.018 --> 00:09:53.030
>> Yep, we talk a lot about hot keys.

213
00:09:53.030 --> 00:09:54.570
There are some very simple ones.

214
00:09:54.570 --> 00:09:59.010
The ones that I mention are the ones you
probably gonna want to commit to memory or

215
00:09:59.010 --> 00:09:59.920
write down.

216
00:09:59.920 --> 00:10:02.870
And then again,
I will show this several times,

217
00:10:02.870 --> 00:10:04.380
I'm just gonna go back
to Premiere Pro here.

218
00:10:04.380 --> 00:10:08.845
There is a keyboard shortcuts area
that you can fire up and look through.

219
00:10:08.845 --> 00:10:14.363
The other thing is too, I didn't really
mention this in lessons, but one

220
00:10:14.363 --> 00:10:20.160
thing that a lot of people do is instead
of adding or modifying, they remove.

221
00:10:21.210 --> 00:10:25.220
Because they don't use a lot, and they
will basically clear the keyboard out as

222
00:10:25.220 --> 00:10:27.960
much as they can and
then only add in what they need.

223
00:10:29.040 --> 00:10:31.706
>> Yeah, so I think it's just
how you wanna approach it but

224
00:10:31.706 --> 00:10:33.255
put in those hot keys to memory.

225
00:10:33.255 --> 00:10:37.952
And in the show notes, we do have a link
to the Adobe website that has shortcuts

226
00:10:37.952 --> 00:10:39.554
for both Windows and Mac.

227
00:10:39.554 --> 00:10:42.687
And here is another side note,
we are using a Mac here-

228
00:10:42.687 --> 00:10:43.780
>> Yep, we're just using a Mac.

229
00:10:43.780 --> 00:10:47.112
>> And so we're using Mac terminology like
the finder, but if you're in Windows,

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne discuss the basics for getting started in Premiere Pro by exploring the different settings when you first launch the program and create a new file. They also determine why it is best to use the media browser in Premiere Pro rather than the Finder and explain the concepts of scratch disks and ingest media.
episodes.title: Getting Started in Premiere Pro

episodes.description: Organizing media for your Premiere Pro project is an important first step to making a great video. This episode explores the project panel, the source monitor panel, and the program monitor in the Premiere Pro interface. We also determine why blue is so important to notice in working within the panels.
episodes.title: Project Organization

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne take a deeper dive into organizing projects, introduce the left side vs the right side, and add custom meta data columns to items in the project panel.
episodes.title: Even More Project Organization

episodes.description: In this episode, we examine the source monitor panel buttons, options, shortcuts for previewing clips, adding in and out points, and creating segments to add to the project panel. James also demonstrates how to create custom keyboard shortcuts in Premiere Pro.
episodes.title: The Source Monitor

episodes.description: We begin creating our first edited story by adding clips to the timeline. James shows different ways to drag and drop into the timeline or the program panel as well as using keyboard shortcuts for adding clips to insert, overwrite, overlay, replace, and insert before/after into the sequence.
episodes.title: Our First Story

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne review different options for navigating in the timeline. James demonstrates how to work with linked clips and how to isolate video from audio. He also shows how to trim and edit audio tracks.
episodes.title: Navigating the Timeline

episodes.description: In this episode, James adds a simple title to the timeline in our first edited story using the legacy title tool and creates a simple opacity fade using keyframes.
episodes.title: Simple Titles

episodes.description: In this episode, we examine the presets and options for exporting a project in Premiere Pro, including the time tuner option. We also discuss the ripple trim tool for trimming clips in the timeline.
episodes.title: Simple Export

episodes.description: James shows off his fun gadgets for shooting video with a smart phone and how to add transitions to sequences. He reviews timeline options in Premiere Pro preferences, hotkeys for inserting clips for the source panel to the timeline, and options for working in the panels to modify transition settings.  James also covers how to manage panels and workspace presets as well as create custom workspaces.
episodes.title: Adding Transitions

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne discuss trimming techniques using hotkeys, editing in trim mode, the importance of the K key, and playback options in the preferences.
episodes.title: Simple Trimming

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne discuss the reasons how to replace footage from the project panel, interpret footage for speed effects, snapping of the playhead in the preferences, match frame for creating effects, and effects parameters in the effects panel.
episodes.title: Adding Effects

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne work with still images in Premiere Pro. They cover how to import a folder of images, modify stills duration in the preferences, and add stills to the timeline. They also demonstrate how to add markers in a clip and a sequence, then add images to the markers through the automate to sequence command. Finally, they show how to animate stills using effects parameters.
episodes.title: Working with Stills

episodes.description: Vonne and James continue with more effects, specifically covering speed effects. James demonstrates how to modify clip speed/duration, the rate stretch tool, and time remapping. They also cover advanced workspace manipulation.
episodes.title: Speed Effects

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne dive into the world of color correction in Premiere Pro. They review the lumetri scope panel and how to read the graphs. They also demonstrate how to use the basic correction, creative, and curves panels within the lumetri color panel group.
episodes.title: Color Correction

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne continue to explore how to color correct in Premiere Pro. They demonstrate how to use the color wheels, HSL secondary, and vignette panels within the lumetri color panel group. They also cover adjustment layers and review some obsolete effects.
episodes.title: Even More Color Correction

episodes.description: James and Vonne cover the essentials of sound editing. They review the audio settings in the preferences, the merge clips command, and the audio track mixer. They also cover how to add effects and create a live mix in the audio track mixer.
episodes.title: Essential Sound Editing

episodes.description: Make it pop! This is every designer or editorâ€™s favorite request. In this episode, James demonstrates some fun tips and tricks while combining and expanding upon all the skills covered in the previous episodes so far in the series. He explores the shadow highlight effect, creating a vignette using the legacy vignette using the legacy title tool and opacity, and nesting clips.
episodes.title: Make it Pop

episodes.description: In this episode, James and Vonne discuss how to setup a shoot with multiple cameras and creating a multicamera source sequence in Premiere Pro. James also demonstrates how to edit in real time with the multicamera view in the program monitor.
episodes.title: Mulitcamera Editing

episodes.description: 360 degree video is the new wild wild west of video editing.  In this episode, James introduces how Premiere Pro works with 360 video and audio. He discusses creating a new VR sequence and its settings, switching VR display mode in the program panel, adding the binaural effect on the master track in the track mixer, adding the panner ambisonic effect on the track in the timeline, and exporting options.
episodes.title: 360 Degree Video

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and James show how to create a timelapse video by importing an image sequence.
episodes.title: Timelapse

episodes.description: There are other programs within the Creative Cloud that can help step up your productivity. In this episode, James demonstrates how Prelude CC can assist in inputting media as well as Media Encoder to help with outputting finished sequences. He also reviews the remove unused command, the project manager, and how to create new ingest presets.
episodes.title: Step Up Your Input and Output

episodes.description: There is an app for that! James shows off some of his favorite apps for mobile devices to assist in shooting and editing video.
episodes.title: Outside Help
